description: From Old French pocher (“to poke”); akin to poach.

verbs.description: potch (third-person singular simple present potches, present participle potching, simple past and past participle potched)

examples: Afterwards, the second pasture should be treated in the same manner, and the rest in course, feeding the wettest pasture after the driest, that the soil may be less potched.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Australia, mineralogy, gemmology) A type of rough opal without colour, and therefore not worth selling.
examples: Discusses the difference between potch opal and common opal. The terms are often used synonymously, but this writer shows that potch is found only in association with precious opal and differs from common opal in its structure quite substantially.

verbs.description: potch (third-person singular simple present potches, present participle potching, simple past and past participle potched)

entries.meaning: Obsolete form of poach (to cook in simmering water).
